title: Small gravitational waves in shallow waters

icon_data.statement: This question cultivates an analytical approach to problems. The separate parts provide adequate structure for the student to progress through the question, but the new type of analysis that is required is challenging for some students. The question relates to our life experience in the final parts, by quantifying the speed of a truck based purely on a photo. The more subtle part of this question is the relation between shallow water waves and compression waves. If you can see this analogy then you are starting to master your art!

parts.statement:
A truck travels through shallow water at some speed \(U\). The ratio of \(U\) with \(c\) is known as the Froude number (noted \(\mathrm{Fr}\))
Suppose that the bottom wall is slightly rising in the wave direction. Based on your analysis for the horizontal wall, explain why you expect the wave front to steepen. Relate this finding to your observation of breaking waves on the beach.

worked_solutions.text: If the bottom wall is rising with \(x\), then \(h(x)\) is decreasing. Consequently, \( c=\sqrt{gh} \) would be reducing. This means that compression waves from downstream would be catching up with the ones further upstream (since they travel at reduced speeds). This in turn suggests that the compression waves 'accumulate' as the water level decreases, contributing to the steepening of the compression front which eventually forms a breaking wave.
